en.value: Things are different where I'm from.
Describing places in different countries - Comparatives
Describing places
Here's a tip!

Let's have a look at some words we can use to talk about places we've visited or moved to. Make sure to focus on the example phrases to learn some expressions that we can use to describe a country's or region's culture.
It's traditional to...
The region is famous for...
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
lively
There are many lively areas in the old town.
cosmopolitan
Berlin has a cosmopolitan feel.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
True or false?
I was impressed by New York City, it had such a cosmopolitan feel!
She was surprised by how old-fashioned New York City felt.
"Cosmopolitan" generally means influenced by different countries and cultures.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
There are many [k]lively[/k] areas in the old town.
lovely
traditional
In Spain it's traditional to have a late dinner.
historic
When you visit historic places like churches, you're expected to wear appropriate clothes.
Haggis is a [k]traditional[/k] Scottish dish, but not everyone likes it.
historic
Split's historic center is much bigger than I expected.
He's talking about Split's old town.
Match the words with their definitions.
lively
traditional
historic
full of life and activities
long-established custom
from ancient times
picturesque
Peru is famous for its picturesque views.
noisy
Her window faced a noisy street in a touristy area.
Seville is one of the most picturesque places I've ever seen.
He's never been to a city as busy as Seville.
"Picturesque" means something is as beautiful as a great painting.
What's another word for "noisy"?
loud
annoying
boring
crowded
We've never seen a city as crowded as Tokyo.
polluted
I would never have thought that Paris was one of the most polluted cities in Europe.
Select the word that means that a place is extremely busy.
Tallin is the least polluted city in Europe.
The city center was very [h]crowded[/h].
Paris is one of the most [k]polluted[/k] cities in Europe.
pollen
polluted
cosmopolitan
crowded
bad or harmful air quality
influenced by different countries and cultures
full of people
Did you notice?
The example phrases we've seen are a good way of describing a place in greater detail. Have a look below to see these phrases again on their own:
You're expected to...
The city has a ... feel.
I've never seen something as ... as ...
I would never have thought that...
Select the words in the correct order.
[k]London[/k] [k]has[/k] [k]a[/k] [k]cosmopolitan[/k] [k]feel.[/k]
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
When you visit historic places like churches, you're [k]expected to[/k] wear appropriate clothes.
excited for
Select the word that best describes the picture.
historic
cosmopolitan
noisy
We saw such [k]picturesque[/k] places on our trip, it felt like a dream.
polluted
Listen to the audio. How does Sally describe Rome?
The tourist attractions were busy.
The city was extremely polluted.
The streets were quite noisy.
They stayed in a [k]lively[/k] area with lots of bars and restaurants.
Complete the sentence to describe a busy and fun neighbourhood.
large
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
I love the [k]c[/k][k]o[/k][k]s[/k]mo[k]p[/k]ol[k]i[/k][k]t[/k][k]a[/k]n feel of big cities.
They don't like how [k]noisy[/k] cities are, so they usually go to the countryside.
nosy
When the air quality in a city is bad or even harmful, we call it...
polluted.
problematic.
pleaded.
Select the word that can refer to long established routines or customs of a culture.
The parade in Granada was crowded and noisy but everybody was dressed in [h]traditional[/h] clothes. It was beautiful.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
There are many [k]lively[/k] areas in the old town.
Complete the sentence to describe something as loud.
We were trying to get away from the [k]noisy[/k] city.
Peru is famous for its pictur[k]e[/k][k]s[/k][k]q[/k][k]u[/k][k]e[/k] views.
Seville is one of the most [k]picturesque[/k] places I've ever seen.
When you visit [k]historic[/k] places like churches, you're expected to wear appropriate clothes.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
We really enjoyed the [k]cosmopolitan[/k] atmosphere of the city.
influenced by different countries and cultures
Complete the sentence to describe a place that is packed with people.
The Plaza del Sol was [k]crowded[/k].
We saw many people in [k]traditional[/k] dresses.
Do you like lively neighbourhoods or do you prefer historic places? Talk about different experiences you've had by writing in the box or recording yourself speaking.
I prefer the historic places of a city because...
Grammar: Comparatives
Do you remember?

We use comparative adjectives to talk about differences between two or more things.
In this unit we will practise forming sentences with comparatives, and use them to talk about our travels. Let's have a look at some examples.
a train is faster than a bus
the beach is more crowded than the museum.
The hotel in Beijing was nicer than the one in New York.
This sentence is comparing two hotels.
We form comparatives in two different ways: 1. one-syllable adjective + "-er" ending + "than" 2. "more/less" + adjective of 2 or more syllables + "than"
1. Mexico City is warmer than Toronto.
2. The hotel in Chicago was less luxurious than the hotel in Moscow.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Trams in Rome are [k]slower[/k] [k]than[/k] trams in Amsterdam.
more
that
Our last trip was [k]more[/k] enjoyable than this one.
the
Memorise the word(s).
noisier than
The restaurant is noisier today than it was yesterday.
Don't forget!

Adjectives ending in "-y" change their ending to "-ier" in a comparison.
When an adjective ends in a vowel + a consonant, we double that consonant before adding "-er".
happy - happier
big - bigger
Shanghai is big[k]g[/k][k]e[/k][k]r[/k] than Paris.
Remember!
good - "better"
bad - "worse"
Food in Italy is better than food in the U.K.
There are some irregular comparative adjectives:
Select the phrase that has no comparative adjective.
There are more shops in London than in Bath.
I am happier today than I was yesterday.
The film is better than the book.
We can use "more / less ... than" to compare nouns to each other. We use "fewer" instead of "less" when the noun is countable.
There are more bicycles in Amsterdam than in Warsaw.
There are fewer people in St Petersburg than in Moscow.
There is less snow in Snowdonia than in the Alps.
[k]There are[/k] [k]more[/k] [k]beaches in[/k] [k]Australia than[/k] [k]in France.[/k]
There were [k]fewer[/k] museums than I expected.
True or false?
Priya enjoyed her visit to the Louvre.
I enjoyed the tour of the Louvre. It was bigger and more interesting than I expected.
Select all the words that make this phrase a comparison.
It was [h]bigger[/h] and [h]more[/h] [h]interesting[/h] [h]than[/h] I expected.
Use the comparative to fill the gaps in this sentence.
I expected lots of tourists, but Gdansk was [k]more[/k] peaceful than I thought!
than
Use the comparative to fill the gaps in this sentence.
In my opinion, the centre of Vienna was [k]less[/k] old-fashioned than Prague.
as
as many as
James brought as many bags as Juliana.

To say that two things are equal in some way, we say that something is "as" + adjective + "as" something else. When we talk about equal quantities, we say "as many" + noun + "as". Let's look at some examples:
Istanbul is as crowded as London.
There are as many museums in Athens as in Rome.
Sebastian is [k]as[/k] [k]excited[/k] as Ana.
more
than
Our trip to Peru was as wonderful as our trip to Colombia. I love South America!
Amelie enjoyed her trip.
Select all of the words that make comparative phrases.
Dubai is [h]hotter[/h] [h]than[/h] Paris.
There are [h]fewer[/h] [h]people[/h] in St Petersburg [h]than[/h] in Moscow.
Match the beginning and end of the sentences.
There are more
This restaurant is
Istanbul is as
beaches in Australia than in France.
noisier now than before.
crowded as London.
Listen to the audio: how does Amelie feel about her holiday?
She liked Peru and Colombia the same amount.
She liked Peru more than Colombia.
She liked Colombia more than Peru.
Hanoi was great, but this year I want to visit a [k]less[/k] touristy city.
[k]The centre[/k] [k]of Vienna[/k] [k]was[/k] [k]less[/k] [k]old-fashioned[/k] [k]than Prague.[/k]
Colombian food is [k]more interesting than|less interesting than[/k] Hungarian food.
Complete the sentence to type the comparative form of "interesting" that you think best fits.
Match the phrases with their uses:
as interesting as
more/less interesting than
two things are equal
two things are different
There are [k]as[/k] [k]many[/k] museums in Athens as in Rome.
more
less
[k]Gdansk was[/k] [k]more[/k] [k]peaceful[/k] [k]than I[/k] [k]thought.[/k]
Our trip to Peru was [k]as wonderful as[/k] our trip to Colombia!
My best friend is [k]as[/k] tall as me.
more
In my opinion, the centre of Vienna was [k]less old-fashioned than|less old fashioned than[/k] Prague.
James brought [k]as many bags as[/k] Juliana.
[k]Dubai is[/k] [k]more[/k] [k]cosmopolitan[/k] [k]than[/k] [k]Moscow.[/k]
Make this sentence positive: "In Milan there were fewer tourists than in Naples."
In Milan there were [k]more tourists than in Naples[/k]
Think of two places you have visited. Tell us how they were similar or different experiences. Write in the box or record yourself speaking.
I went to Paris and Tokyo last year. Tokyo was more cosmopolitan than Paris.
